qas.question: Section 6 of the Endangered Species Act provided funding for what purpose?

answers.text: development of programs for management of threatened and endangered species by state wildlife agencies

qas.question: What is one notable drawback with state wildlife agencies creating their own lists?

answers.text: These state lists often include species which are considered endangered or threatened within a specific state but not within all states

qas.question: What states are listing species that are endangered in their own state, but that are not endangered in all other states?
What states do not have their own lists?
What defunded the development of programs for managing endangered species?
What did Section 6 of the act separate boundaries by?

plausible_answers.text: Section 6 of the Endangered Species Act

qas.question: Who funded species within specific states?

context: <b4_0><b6_0>Section 6<b4_0/> of the Endangered Species Act<b6_0/> provided funding for <a0_0>development of programs for management of threatened and endangered species by state wildlife agencies<a0_0/>. Subsequently, lists of endangered and threatened species within their boundaries have been prepared by <b5_0>each state<b5_0/>. <a1_0>These state lists often include species which are considered endangered or threatened within a specific state but not within all states<a1_0/>, and which therefore are not included on the national list of endangered and threatened species. Examples include <a2_0><b3_0>Florida, Minnesota, Maine, and California<b3_0/><a2_0/>.
